content: two-at-a-time fingerless mitts recipe small 36 stitches cast on 4 ½ inches around unstretched used 40 grams of worsted weight yarn large 44 stitches cast on 6 inches around unstretched used 54 grams of worsted weight yarn you will need ● us 6 knitting needle with cable long enough for you to comfortably work magic loop my needle is 29 inches long ● approximately 45-65 grams of worsted weight yarn this pattern is very flexible on yardage and a great stash buster ● 5 locking stitch markers ● darning needle for weaving in ends notes you will be working magic loop two at a time with two balls of yarn i will refer to the first mitt and working yarn as a and the second mitt and working yarn as b when it matters both mitts are worked exactly the same you need 2 balls of worsted yarn and 2 balls of a contrast color if adding stripes you can either weigh out two equal balls using a scale or if your yarn is wound into a center pull skein you can work with one yarn from the outside of the skein and the second from the center pull there are a few tricks you can use to help manage having two or more if you re doing stripes balls of yarn attached to the same project a yarn bowl helps but my favorite trick is putting your yarn in a small ziploc bag and sealing just the middle of the bag so your working yarn comes out the unsealed corners that way your yarns are separate while still being together in one place and protected from getting tangled up recipe two at a time cast-on start by long tail co 18 22 stitches on to your needle with yarn a this is half the amount of total stitches you will need for mitt a drop yarn a and pick up yarn b co 36 44 stitches you now have two groups of cast on stitches on your needle divide group b in half bringing your needles around as if to begin working with magic loop drop yarn b and pick up yarn a to finish casting on the remaining 18 22 stitches for mitt a this part is the most fiddly of the whole project but be patient and you ll get it now you have two groups of stitches each with their own ball of yarn and are set up to begin working in magic loop carefully slide your back needle out and begin working 3x1 rib this cast on is great because you don t need to fiddle around with joining in the round just make sure your cast on isn t twisted and start knitting you ll be knitting half the stitches for mitt a knitting all the stitches for mitt b and then coming back around to the other half of mitt a to finish the round i like to clip a removable stitch marker
